newsitem.title: GREECE: ATHLETICS-HATTESTAD CONQUERS NERVES TO RECAPTURE WORLD TITLE.
newsitem.headline: ATHLETICS-HATTESTAD CONQUERS NERVES TO RECAPTURE WORLD TITLE.

text.p: Norway's Trine Hattestad conquered her nerves on Saturday to recapture the world women's javelin title.
"This was my most nervous competition ever," Hattestad said. "I knew I had to get a big throw out in the first round."
The plan worked to perfection when she unleashed the winning throw of 68.78 metres in the first round.
Australian Joanna Stone ensured the Norwegian could never entirely relax.
"I thought I had won the gold for sure after the first round but then the Australian was throwing further and further and I was getting more worried," Hattestad said.
Hattestad, 31, won the 1993 world title but did not compete in Gothenburg two years ago because she was pregnant with her son Robin, who was born in December, 1995.
She bounced back at the Olympics last year to take a bronze medal but said on Saturday that she had not really got back to her best in time for Atlanta.
Stone, who moved to Australia from Britain as a baby, produced three throws over 68 metres, including personal bests of 68.16 in the second round and 68.64 in the fifth to take the silver medal.
Stone was taken aback by Hattestad's first throw.
"But then I relaxed," Stone said. "It has gone much better than I ever thought it would back home."
Stone attributed her surprise silver medal to the inspiration of watching her compatriot Cathy Freeman take the women's 400 metres gold on Monday.
"Seeing Cath get a gold medal showed me you can do anything you put your mind to," the extrovert Australian added.
Germany's Tanja Damask won the bronze medal with a personal best of 67.12. Finland's Olympic champion Heli Rantanen failed to find her best form and finished 10th.
